Orangelight Feedback

First of all, congratulations on the beta launch! It is hard to overstate how much of an improvement the new system is over the legacy one. Great work.

Apologies for not providing feedback during earlier phases of development, but I do have a few questions/observations that have been gathering dust in the back of my mind, so I thought I would go ahead and share them—better late than never? Sorry in advance if these points have already been addressed.

  1. Are there plans to incorporate authorities data into the catalog interface? This data has long been hidden from users, and exposing it would enhance access.
    • In particular, I was impressed by the work on authorities browsing in Blacklight being done at Cornell, as presented at Code4Lib (http://2016.code4lib.org/Building-a-userfriendly-authorities-browse-in-Blacklight).
    • Are there plans to index series access points for browsing/collocation? Ditto for uniform titles (but see below under “labels”)?
  2. Linked Data/RDF
    • What about URI design for future linked data integration? For example, when/if PUL catalog data is converted to RDF, what will the canonical URIs look like? The current https://pulsearch.princeton.edu/catalog/9575320 is clean, but do we want platform-specific branding like “pulsearch” in a canonical URI? (See, for example, https://www.w3.org/TR/cooluris/ for best practices.) Why not just https://library.princeton.edu/catalog/9575320? The branding would seem to suggest that the catalog is still being thought of as a discrete system rather than just another view onto a larger data graph. In general, it might be good to have a broader discussion—at least in terms of information sharing, if nothing else—about the steps that are currently being taken to build linked data readiness into PUL’s evolving systems/platforms.
    • Are there plans to integrate more robust RDFa markup into the HTML views? It looks as though only out-of-the-box Blacklight RDFa is currently included? This would seem to be fairly low-hanging fruit and a way to (potentially) boost SEO and integrate PUL catalog data into the wider Web, etc., etc.
  3. Labels
    • Relationship designators. +1 for this. However, are there plans to display multiples relationship designators? Currently, it seems that only the last one (which might not be the “most important”) is being displayed. For example, in https://pulsearch.princeton.edu/catalog/9575320, Leon Hirszman is both the film director and the screenwriter, but is only labeled as the screenwriter.
    • “Uniform Title.” Minor point, but “Uniform title” is an obsolete term no longer used under current (RDA) cataloging rules. A more “correct” label would be “Authorized access point.”
    • “Form genre” as a label doesn’t make much sense. Should at least be “Form/genre.”
  4. Content/media/carrier type(s). So, RDA has the 3xx fields for indicating content, media, and carrier type(s) of a resource. Are these currently being used in any way? Users might like to know, for example, that a resource is primarily a moving image/DVD, but that it also contains text/printed material. Again, see https://pulsearch.princeton.edu/catalog/9575320 for an example. The predominant format could be taken from the leader, then more granular info could be derived from 3xx fields.
  5. Geo browse. To be supported at a later date? Would be great to see some use made of those pesky 043 codes I keep typing.
  6. Speaking of pesky MARC fields: bibliographic references. Maybe a facet for resources that include bibliographic references? Do users care about this?
  7. Potential bug? See https://pulsearch.princeton.edu/catalog/9574948, which includes an “Other versions” link that is not present in the MARC data. Further, it links to a seemingly unrelated resource. Same publisher, but otherwise unrelated. Unclear what’s going on there.

Please let me know if I can follow up on or clarify any of these points. Keep up the good work!

—Tim
